p: Zika virus (ZIKV) is a (re-)emerging virus that was originally identified in 1947 in Uganda [ 1] but has now caused a series of epidemics in Micronesia [ 2], the South Pacific [ 3], and the Americas [ 4]. To date, 84 countries or territories reported ZIKV transmissions [ 5]. Initially considered a harmless infection in humans, ZIKV may cause disease in adults, including meningoencephalitis [ 6], myelitis [ 7], thrombocytopenia [ 8], and Guillain–Barré syndrome [ 9, 10]. It is now established that ZIKV can be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy, where it can cause fetal demise, microcephaly, and other congenital problems [ 11], which may develop in up to 46% of the cases [ 12]. Thus, ZIKV infection poses a high risk for human health, as vaccines and therapeutics are not available.
